Description: Fragment of neck of black-figure painted pottery situla. Standing cock, incised rosette, part of another cock or hen. Purple for comb and wattle, perhaps on ruff and base of wing, and on alternate petals of rosette. The incised line on the far right should be from the uppermost big feather of the tail.
Curator's comments: Possibly from the same pot as BM GR 1888.0208.9.e and 1888.0208.16.a, but not from the same pot as Pl. GB 601, 6 (as Petrie and BMC have it). The cock's ruff resembles that of Clazomenian (e.g. Pls. 585, 1; 587, 16-17; 613, 2), but the treatment of tail and wing is different; compare here Attic black figure cocks of c.560-550 B.C. (A. Rumpf, Sakonides, pl. 5b and d - one in the manner of Lydos and the other by the painter of Vatican 309, in the opinion of Sir John Beazley).
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B106.9.2)
CVA British Museum 8 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 13, British Museum 8 (Pl. GB 604, 13 (and Pl. GB 597, 4)) (Group C20)
Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (pl. xxxvi, 10a)
Weber 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus anderen ägyptischen Fundorten (TD 260)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.211)
